context: What are the non-biogenic sources of isoprene in marine waters, and why is such isoprene production potentially greater in polar waters than in tropical waters? Why do higher plants emit DMS, and what are the selection pressures on DMSP in the terrestrial context? Did early land plants influence palaeo-sulfur cycles? Dimethyl sulfide (DMS) is an important organic sulfur compound released into the atmosphere both through natural and anthropogenic processes. DMS is produced in nature by phytoplankton in the oceans and is usually oxidized to other sulfur compounds, such as dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO), dimethyl sulfone (DMSO2) and sulfate. Additionally, certain anthropogenic processes result in the emission of VOSCs, including DMS, DMDS, and methyl mercaptan (MM), from waste water plants, oil industry sources, sewer systems, and paper industry sources [3–5]. Moreover, DMS is regularly used as an intermediate or as a starter in the plastics industry and in pharmaceutical plants.
